title: 106_hr3770
content: The Act titled "Secure Online Communication Enforcement Act of 2000" enhances privacy protection for information on computer networks. The Act "Secure Online Communication Enforcement Act of 2000" amends Section 2703(b) of title 18, United States Code, allowing a governmental entity to require a provider of remote computing service to disclose electronic communication contents under a warrant or subpoena. The Act "Secure Online Communication Enforcement Act of 2000" amends Section 2703(b) of title 18, United States Code, allowing a governmental entity to require a provider of remote computing service to disclose electronic communication contents under a warrant or trial subpoena, with provisions for serving the subpoena to the subscriber or customer for challenge. Amendments include indenting and specifying applicability. SEC. 3. ENHANCEMENT OF SECURE ON-LINE COMMUNICATIONS. Enhancement of secure online communications through amendments to the limitations on disclosure of communication records under section 2703(c) of title 18, United States Code. Amendments include expanding the scope to cover operators of Internet websites and third parties. Amendments to section 2703(c) of title 18, United States Code enhance secure online communications by allowing disclosure of communication records to non-government entities under specific circumstances. This includes situations where disclosure is necessary for providing services, protecting rights or property, subscriber/customer request, or with their consent. The amendments to section 2703(c) of title 18, United States Code allow for disclosure of communication records to non-government entities under specific circumstances, including providing services, protecting rights or property, subscriber/customer request, or with their consent. The amendments also cover limitations on disclosure of information generated in the process of accessing or using the Internet, and permit the use of aggregate customer information without individual details. The amendments to section 2703(c) of title 18, United States Code allow for disclosure of communication records to non-government entities under specific circumstances. Providers of electronic communication service or remote computing service may not terminate service to individuals who refuse to consent to disclosure of records. Federal preemption prohibits any State or local law regarding disclosure of records covered by this subsection. (g) Conforming Amendment: The subsection heading of the section is amended to include Internet Web Site. (h) Effective Date: The amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment.
